metadata_frame: The following passage comes from In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch, a book of travel and natural description published in 1878 by Charles Dudley Warner, an American essayist.
main_question:
It is alternately invaded by the hyperborean legions and by the wilting sirens of the tropics. Icicles hang always on its northern heights; its seacoasts are fringed with mosquitoes. There is for a third of the year a contest between the icy air of the pole and the warm wind of the gulf. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect] It is the normal condition in New England.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch, a book of travel and natural description published in 1878 by Charles Dudley Warner, an American essayist.
main_question:
I should get close to the log, crawl under my hat, strike the match, see it catch, flicker, almost go out (the reader painfully excited by this time), blaze up, nearly expire, and finally fire the punk, thank God! And I said to myself, "The public don't want any more of this thing: it is played out. Either have a box of matches, or let the first one catch fire." In this gloomy mood I plunged along. The prospect was cheerless; [masked clause describing a cause or reason]. I fancied I could hear the tread of the stealthy brutes following their prey.

for, apart from the discomfort that fire would cause, it tends to attract wild beasts
for we had not expected to pass that night in the woods
because I knew that if I failed to set my fire ablaze with this match, the wolves would be upon me
because the valley lay shrouded in a perpetual gray mist, with no sign of life

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch, a book of travel and natural description published in 1878 by Charles Dudley Warner, an American essayist.
main_question:
When I guessed that I must be close to the river, I suddenly stepped into mud up to my ankles. It was the road, running, of course, the wrong way, but still the blessed road. It was a mere canal of liquid mud; but man had made it, and it would take me home. I was at least three miles from the point where I supposed I was near at sunset, and I had before me a toilsome walk of six or seven miles, most of the way in a ditch; [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]. I was safe; I knew where I was; and I could have walked till morning.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a tension or contrast]:
source_title: In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch
source_genre: book of travel and natural description
answer_strings: but it is truth to say I enjoyed every step of it
but it is true to say that I hated every step of it
however, of dropping off to sleep, somebody unfortunately notes a drop of water on his face; this is followed by another drop; in an instant a stream is established
but a succession of falls, cascades, flumes, and pools, that would delight an artist
yet I was exhausted and famished
though the darkness of night could hide unseen perils
passage: I was at least three miles from the point where I supposed I was near at sunset, and I had before me a toilsome walk of six or seven miles, most of the way in a ditch; but it is truth to say I enjoyed every step of it.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch, a book of travel and natural description published in 1878 by Charles Dudley Warner, an American essayist.
main_question:
The spur we chose for our escape looked smooth in the distance; but we found it bristling with obstructions, dead balsams set thickly together, slashes of fallen timber, and every manner of woody chaos; and when at length we swung and tumbled off the ledge to the general slope, we exchanged only for more disagreeable going. The slope for a couple of thousand feet was steep enough; but it was formed of granite rocks all moss-covered, [masked clause describing an inference or effect].

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch, a book of travel and natural description published in 1878 by Charles Dudley Warner, an American essayist.
main_question:
She knew, by their uncertain yelping up and down the opposite bank, that she had a little respite: she used it, however, to push on until the baying was faint in her ears; and then she dropped, exhausted, upon the ground. This rest, brief as it was, saved her life. Roused again by the baying pack, she leaped forward with better speed, [masked clause conceding a limit or exception]. It was still a race for life; but the odds were in her favor, she thought.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause conceding a limit or exception]:
source_title: In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch
source_genre: book of travel and natural description

though her speed was more exhilarating than it had been in the morning
although they said it was small for a bear
though they were still hidden by a ridge) she turned away towards the north, and kept on at a good pace
except when her strength began to fail
though the pack surged ahead, her lungs burned and she could barely breathe slowly
passage: Roused again by the baying pack, she leaped forward with better speed, though without that keen feeling of exhilarating flight that she had in the morning.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch, a book of travel and natural description published in 1878 by Charles Dudley Warner, an American essayist.
main_question:
He intends no harm: he only gratifies a curiosity to see if he can hit the mark. Where shall he draw the line? Doubtless he might throw a stone at a chipmunk or shout at a loon. Might he fire at a mark with an air-gun that makes no noise? He will not fish or hunt on Sunday (although he is no more likely to catch anything that day than on any other); but may he eat trout that the guide has caught on Sunday, [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]? Is there such a thing as a vacation in religion?

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]:
source_title: In the Wilderness, With a Biographical Sketch
source_genre: book of travel and natural description
answer_strings: if the guide swears he caught them Saturday night
if the guide denies catching them on Saturday
if none of his congregation are present
if such a cave exists
if the guide has taken them legally during the week
provided he does not break the silence of the day
passage: He will not fish or hunt on Sunday (although he is no more likely to catch anything that day than on any other); but may he eat trout that the guide has caught on Sunday, if the guide swears he caught them Saturday right?
